10 minutes. Bitcoin mining is a poisson process. It's memory-less. So at any moment in time, the expected time is always 10 minutes. If you said 5 minutes, don't worry, you are in good company. Craig S. Wright wrote a whole paper based on this error! https://twitter.com/PeterRizun/status/978453208854011904 …

Let's test your knowledge of Bitcoin mining. Bitcoin is designed such that a block is mined every 10 minutes on average. If 5 minutes has passed since the last block was mined, what's the expected amount of time before the next block is mined?

Shitcoin City ain't Bitcoin City ;-) I feel you though. Bitcoin meetups aren't what they used to be.

It seems I feel less nostalgia for the early days in Bitcoin than most. Values & trade offs are more clearly articulated now, many brilliant engineers and entrepreneurs have joined, and many more resources available. Overall I prefer Bitcoin City over Bitcoin Village.

On a relative basis however, Bitcoin gains ground. Ethereum has decoupled from the micro cap coins, is losing terrain faster now. Lack of viable scaling prospects? https://coinmarketcap.com/charts/ pic.twitter.com/uKKgu6DQz4
